title: 110_hr2522
content: The Act is titled the "Congressional Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery Act" and defines modern-day slavery as the control of a person through violence or coercion for purposes of exploitation. Congress finds that modern-day slavery takes various forms and occurs in different industries, violating the dignity of individuals through violence and exploitation. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights prohibits slavery in all its forms, and the US and international community are committed to combating this issue. The United States and the international community are committed to abolishing modern-day slavery in accordance with various international conventions and protocols. The United States prioritizes the abolition of modern-day slavery through international conventions and protocols, including the Declaration of Independence and the 13th amendment to the Constitution. The United States has prioritized combating trafficking in persons, a form of modern-day slavery, through various acts such as the Trafficking Victims Protection Act of 2000 and subsequent reauthorization acts. Importation of goods produced by forced labor is prohibited under the Tariff Act of 1930. Establishment of Commission. The congressional Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery is established with 12 members appointed based on expertise in combating modern-day slavery. The Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery will have 12 members appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Co-chairpersons are designated by the Speaker of the House and the Senate majority leader. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 60 days of the Act's enactment and will meet at the call of either co-chairperson. The Commission on the Abolition of Modern-Day Slavery will have 12 members appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Co-chairpersons are designated by the Speaker of the House and the Senate majority leader. The Commission shall meet at the call of either Co-chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum. SEC. 5. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is mandated to conduct a comprehensive study on modern-day slavery, its various forms, and the reasons for its persistence. This includes examining the lack of enforcement of anti-slavery laws, corruption among officials, and the vulnerabilities of marginalized populations. The Commission will review programs of relevant governmental agencies and examine efforts by foreign countries and multilateral organizations to prevent or combat modern-day slavery in all its forms. The Commission will review programs of relevant governmental agencies and examine efforts by foreign countries and multilateral organizations to prevent or combat modern-day slavery in all its forms. Additionally, the Commission will advise Congress on supporting efforts to eradicate modern-day slavery, evaluate models and strategies for prevention, rescue, rehabilitation, prosecution, and increasing accountability. The Commission will evaluate current US trade policy's impact on modern slavery, list top countries with high numbers of slaves, assess effectiveness of laws against importing goods produced by slaves. The Commission will evaluate the importation of goods produced through forced or child labor, assess US Government procurement policies, and examine the economic impact of successful anti-slavery efforts. Recommendations for legislative action will be made. The Commission will recommend legislative and administrative actions to combat modern-day slavery, including incorporating best practices into anti-slavery programs, increasing accountability in governments that tolerate slavery, and eliminating importation of slave-made goods. They will also make specific recommendations to prevent the US Government's procurement of slave-made goods and services. The Commission will submit a report to congressional leaders within 11 months of the Act's enactment, detailing the results of the study on combating modern-day slavery and the recommendations developed. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather necessary information from governmental agencies, and receive evidence to carry out the Act. Additionally, the Commission's personnel matters are outlined in Section 7. The Commission members who are not federal government officers or employees will be compensated at a rate equal to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Officers or employees of the United States serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Members are also entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The co-chairpersons of the Commission have the authority to appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. They can also determine their compensation independently. The Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws. The pay rates for personnel cannot exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The co-chairpersons can procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 8. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized for the Commission in fiscal year 2008 as needed, with no time limit on availability.
